Pyfood APIÂ¶

Pyfood is a simple Python package to process food, in different languages. At the core of Pyfood is the concept of a shelf embedded in a given region, a certain month_id and optionally a source language. You can load a shelf embedded in France in January with the following Python snippet:

from pyfood.utils import Shelf
shelf = Shelf(region='France', month_id=0)

Pyfood currently works with the following regions: France ðŸ‡«ðŸ‡·, Italy ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡¹, Spain ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸, Portugal ðŸ‡µðŸ‡¹, Germany ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª, EU ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡º (Europe, default), United Kingdom ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§, Canada ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¦, Japan ðŸ‡¯ðŸ‡µ, Israel ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡± and Senegal ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡³. It supports the following languages EN (English), FR (French), ES (Spanish), IT (Italian), DE (German), PT (Portuguese) and UN (Universal, default)

Pyfood shelfÂ¶

Pyfood shelf embedded in a given region, month_id and optionally source language

process_ingredients(food_list: List[str], qty_list: Optional[List[str]], unit_list: Optional[List[str]], lang_dest: Optional[str], revisit: bool = False, infer_nutri: bool = False, serving: int = 1)[source]Â¶

Labels a list of ingredients, e.g., from a recipe or a basket of food, and saves attributes / labels in self.tags

Parameters

  • food_list (list) â€“ List of food name in self.lang_source

  • qty_list (list) â€“ List of quantities or None

  • unit_list (list) â€“ List of units or None

  • lang_dest (str) â€“ Target language, default self.lang_source

  • revisit (bool) â€“ Infer Recipe2BetterRecipe, default False

  • infer_nutri (bool) â€“ Infer nutrition scores, default False

  • serving (int) â€“ Number of portions, default 1.

Returns

tags â€“ Extracted ingredients (ingredients_by_taxon, HS, revisited), predicted nutrition (allergies, energy, macro, minerals, vitamines) and labels (vege, vegan, seasonality)

Return type

dict

text2food(food_name: str = 'apple', threshold: float = 0.0) → Tuple[source]Â¶

Retrieves ingredient from vocabulary using tdfidf and cosine_similarity. Returns food id, taxon and seasonality.

Parameters
